I'm highly in favor of implicit casting from 1x1 matrix to scalar in the case of displaying a matrix element value in a print statement. I think that is a very big win for usability.

I also think `rowVars(a)` is much easier on the eyes than `as.scalar(rowVars(as.matrix(a)))`, since it focuses on the essence rather than on the conversions, although I don't know if this implicit conversion brings up other issues. I don't have a deep enough knowledge of the project to make a more informed comment as to the ramifications of such conversions. Great question for @mboehm7

Well, I also think this would be useful but it's hard to get right in the general case. We already did something similar for leftindexing w/ scalars, e.g, A[b,c] = s that originally required a right-hand-side matrix. The problem of adding this after right indexing is that we don't necessarily see (especially during validate) where the output is used. This causes many problems due to changed signatures of statement blocks, e.g., in case of conditional control flow, fixed function signatures, or operations that only operator over matrices, etc. I'm not in favor of modifying operations that users would only use in case of matrices (e.g., unary aggregates, matrix mult, etc). Yes, it might happen that during runtime, we have a 1x1 matrix but that is usually not known during validate in these cases. Please also keep in mind that this has nothing to do with the underlying data representation but language semantics. 

I would be fine though to add this for the restricted cases of (1) string concatenations (+ or append), and (2) print statements. These cases would be simple to realize and would probably already solve 95% of related usability concerns.

@mboehm7 Great, thanks for the detailed feedback and guidance as always.  The continued exploration of the engine is quite interesting.  Adding this specifically for string concatenation and print statements would definitely help for usability.

---

Just in the interests of continuing to **learn** more about the engine, it would be very interesting to extend this conversation further.  If we take the `rowVars(a)` example above (yes, agreed that it's not a likely use-case, but nonetheless, let's use it as a concrete example), where `a` is a scalar, and apply the concept of injected matrix casting in order to make this statement correct, it seems like there would be two options.  We could tie the casting to the `a` variable, as in a replacement of `a` with `as.matrix(a)`, or tie the casting to the `rowVars(...)` expression, as in a replacement of `rowVars(...)` with `rowVars(as.matrix(...))`.   As you confirmed (if I understand correctly), the former case should cause issues as it changes the datatype of the `a` variable from a scalar to a matrix, without giving attention to where else in the script `a` is being used.  My thought with this experiment was that the latter case of associating the casting with the expression that requires it (which would only be the case when the input is a scalar datatype), as in `rowVars(as.matrix(...))`, would be a safer option as it would not interfere with the `a` variable and any other uses of it in the script.  Thus, when validating, I was attempting to add these casting statements directly as inputs of the expressions needing them due to being supplied a scalar input while requiring a matrix input, such as `rowVars(a)`.  Once I added the matrix casting, I would mark the current expression (current being the `rowVars()` expression, in this case) as needing validation again, and then re-run the validating step on that expression.

If you have the time, @mboehm7, it would very interesting to gain any further thoughts/insights regarding this concept and it's interactions with the engine.  Just for the sake of learning, as I mentioned.
Thanks @dusenberrymw for starting the build!

@dusenberrymw, yes you're absolutely right. Whenever you tie this to the consumer, you can easily ensure correctness for scalar->matrix. All you would need is a lookup table of builtin function arguments that require matrix inputs. Without this awareness, we would affect the result data type of builtin functions like round(x) that also work on scalars. We do similar things for (1) scalar-matrix data type conversions for left indexing, but also (2) value-type conversions for function inputs (e.g., a function with integer signature but called with a double). For matrix->scalar (even if tied to the consumer), it's already more subtle because it's size dependent (only in case of 1x1 matrices) - otherwise it might be very confusing for a user to get errors in case of larger matrices from the injected cast instead of the print. As already described, binding it to the source expression A[1,1] creates many issues because we compile different instructions for different data type combinations. 

I think we all agree that it would be useful to do implicit matrix->scalar casts for print and string concatenation. So let's get this in. Thanks for initiating this discussion guys.
@dusenberrymw I like the idea, but could please also do a test with the wink library that we use for reading the meta data file? Maybe we could get rid of this custom string concatenation code?

@mboehm7 Thanks for the extended discussion!

@Wenpei Yes, I agree that would make more sense from a user's perspective.  R, Python (NumPy), and Matlab/Octave all use the same idea of treating a full right-index result as a scalar value, rather than a 1x1 matrix.  Furthermore, Matlab/Octave has no distinction between the two at the user level.  

@mboehm7 What are your thoughts on this?  While this seems like a good idea at the language level, I'm sure there may have been a good reason/goal behind the original decision.

ok wrt right indexing, let's try not to cycle the discussion (please see above, let me know if more clarification is needed). In comparison to R (which is an interpreter), it is more difficult in SystemML because we compile different instructions for different data type combinations.

Oh, yeah I understand from our discussion that adding _casts_ to full right indexing (i.e. `X[1,4]`) could cause problems.  Perhaps though this could be interpreted as a bigger design discussion -- what if full right indexing natively returned a scalar value?  We wouldn't be changing it post-processing such as with the casting, but rather the instruction would natively result in a scalar value.

Well the problem is consistency: how do you treat X[a:b, c:d] or X[a,] without knowing a, b, c, d and the dimensions of the input matrix (especially during validate) - then you would end up with some indexing expressions that result in matrices and some others in scalars for the same 1x1 matrix. Also, we want to have the distinction between scalars and matrices because we compile completely different operations in the distributed case.

Yeah, I agree consistency could be an issue.  However, what if we **only** assume a scalar output for the case `X[a,b]`?  In that case, it doesn't matter what `a` and `b` are -- the result is still going to be one single value.  If the user were to instead use `X[a:b, c:d]`, we just return a matrix.  Even if that evaluates to `X[1:1, 1:1]`, the user was still using range indexing, so a matrix was desired and/or expected.  This is the design that Python (NumPy) uses as well.  If we follow this approach, we could define very clear distinctions for the user, and perhaps this would also allow us to maintain clear distinctions internally as well.

@dusenberrymw please don't get me wrong, of course we could define some specific cases but I'm afraid that this would cause more problems than it solves. User could easily run into issues where in one branch they do point indexing, in the other range indexing, and we "automatically" change the data type in one, leading to compile/runtime errors after the branch.

@mboehm7, @shirisht I explored using the Wink JSON library for writing, and I've replaced the string concatenation code.  I used an `OrderedJSONObject` so that the metadata files will have a consistent ordering for the user's benefit.

@mboehm7 Okay, we don't have to pursue this, although if we made the decision that a `X[a,b]` right index is an operation that returns a scalar (natively, rather than in a post-processing step), then validation of conditional control flow should catch any such issues.  At that point, it would be up to the user to understand that `X[1,1]` and `X[1:1,1:1]` are different indexing operations, which already seems natural.

just to clarify, we already do these checks for data type mismatches of variables from conditional control flow, which would give a compile error if this situation happen to be in an unconditionally executed block; otherwise if it's unclear if we execute the block, it only gives a warning - unfortunately, users typically completely ignore warnings which will lead to runtime errors.

1) Based on which rule of thumb did you decide to centralize configurations in MRConfigurationName vs leaving them as they are in the code? Only configurations with differences in v1/v2?  
2) Could you also please simplify (shorten) the constant names ("MR" prefix instead of "MAPREDUCE" etc)?
great thanks.
@mboehm7 Yes, packages can be excluded using the excludePackageNames configuration property. Do you know which packages you'd like to exclude (or include)?

well, I would like to include the api package as well as helper classes like MatrixCharacteristics etc that are used in these apis - essentially everything a user that comes in through mlcontext or jmlc would need.

1)
When executing SystemML, there were 5 log warnings (to the console) each time it was run about deprecated hadoop configuration properties (io.sort.mb, mapred.job.tracker, mapred.task.tracker.task-controller, mapred.local.dir, and mapred.system.dir). These were old properties that needed to be updated. So this PR is basically concerned with only these properties so that users don't see a bunch of deprecation warnings when they run SystemML.

Moving them to MRConfigurationName allows for conditionally setting these properties based on Hadoop v1 vs v2, thus eliminating the deprecation warnings for v2 and still supporting v1.

From a code maintenance standpoint, I believe that ALL Hadoop configuration properties should eventually be moved to constants in MRConfigurationName. This has several benefits:
1) centralizes all properties in a single place so you can go to one file and know which properties are being used in the project.
2) if a developer comments-out a constant in MRConfigurationName, the IDE immediately reports to the developer all of the locations where the constant is being used (or alternatively, developer can look up all the references to the constant in the project).
3) also eliminates the multiple string instances (which can be error-prone) with constants so that there is no chance of typos in the multiple string instances when referring to the constants.

---

2)
If MAPREDUCE is changed to MR, then there is less of a direct correspondence between the constant names and the properties that they represent (such as MAPREDUCE_TASK_IO_SORT_MB representing "mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb"). Although MR would be assumed to represent MAPREDUCE when dealing with Hadoop, so that's probably a good idea to reduce the size of the constants to make them easier to work with. It's nice if a developer can do code completion of the constants and immediately know which property is actually being set based on the name of the constant. (I based all the constant names on the v2 versions of the properties.)

I'll go ahead and change MAPREDUCE to MR.

I'd also like to gather feedback for an update the 'distributed' release of SystemML to have the suffix 'cluster' attached, in order to make it easy for an end user to distinguish from the 'standalone' package.  

**Previously**, we generated the following releases (omitting the tar files):

`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating.zip`
`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-standalone.zip`
`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-src.zip`

**Now**, we would generate the following releases (omitting the tar files):

`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-cluster.zip`
`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-standalone.zip`
`system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-src.zip`

The goal here would be to reduce confusion for the end user as to which package to download.

@mboehm7, @shirisht, @deroneriksson, @lresende Thoughts?
Personally I like the idea of -cluster so I know the purpose of that release package. It reduces confusion.

I don't have a too strong opinion on that but I would prefer the existing naming scheme (except for renaming system-ml to systemml). In any case, please make sure that system-ml-0.9.0-incubating.zip is identified as the "default" download. From my perspective, giving the "cluster" prefix can be confusing because cluster/standalone would be seen as alternatives, which they are not: systemml-standalone is a specialization of systemml (because it just includes additional libaries).

I definitely agree with @mboehm7 that I prefer the name systemml to system-ml.

WRT other release package naming, I was rather confused 2 days ago when I was trying to validate the releases since there were so many release packages to go through (unzip this jar, untargz this targz, unzip this zip, unzip this src zip and build, etc). I was particularly confused by "system-ml-0.9.0-incubating.zip". I had to open it to say to myself "This contains the jar and the algorithms, and there are no standalone scripts, so this must be what I would use to run an algorithm on a cluster".

I do see @mboehm7 's point that the standalone is a specialization of the other. I don't have a strong opinion about "-cluster". I think my confusion arises because there are so many release packages and it's hard to visually distinguish among the release packages what I should download.

If system-ml-0.9.0-incubating-standalone.zip has all the functionality of system-ml-0.9.0-incubating.zip plus extras, is the presence of system-ml-0.9.0-incubating.zip itself in some ways redundant so that it should be removed and -standalone should be renamed?

Foks, as these discussions are not being archived on the mailing list, we should not be having them as part of the PR and on the dev list.

Anyway, I am +0.

Thanks for the thoughts.  In general, I think we need to get down to one single release.  @mboehm7 What would it take internally to be able to generate one JAR that could be used for both single node Java execution, as well as any combination of execution modes on Hadoop and Spark?  As I understand it, the main issue currently is that we rely on multiple Hadoop libraries, as well as others, but we can't always package it or we would have conflicts when running on Hadoop or Spark.

Of course, this would be a goal for a future release.
LGTM.

yes, there are advantages to either one approach - could we do a quick poll on the mailing list? This will also bring the discussion there. 

Having a single release would be great but this would require a general abstraction of core data structures. For example classes like MatrixIndexes and MatrixBlock are Hadoop writables - we would need to introduce additional abstractions in order to never touch the wrapper writables in CP. Anyway, the major problems are related to IO and cluster status - this means we would need to write, for example, sequence files by hand (according to the documented format) and emulate any cluster interactions. The bottom line is, it's possible but a ton of work that might right now outweigh its benefit.

@dusenberrymw @niketanpansare 
The javadoc failure for Java 8 was happening because apparently Java 8 is stricter with regards to javadocs (see http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/172). I committed a fix that creates a Java 8 profile that adds a configuration parameter to ignore the doclint warnings that were causing the failure (see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15886209/maven-is-not-working-in-java-8-when-javadoc-tags-are-incomplete).
